title: Lenny Henry felt ‘ashamed’ after discovering biological dad
text:
Lenny was shocked to learn his biological dad was ‘uncle’ Bertie (Picture: Getty Images)

Lenny Henry has opened up about the moment he learned his ‘biological’ father was a man he already knew, and how he used to feel ‘ashamed’ by the truth.

The 61-year-old comedian reveals how his late mother, Winifred, had an affair with a man named Albert Green aka Bertie, not long after arriving in Britain from Jamaica during the second wave of Caribbean immigration in 1957.

Lenny was a result of the affair but was brought up by Winifred and her partner Winston, who treated the comedian as his own child.

When Lenny was 10-years-old, his mother told him to do chores for his ‘uncle’ Bertie to earn pocket money. It wasn’t until 18 months later that Lenny found out the man he worked for every Friday, was actually his biological father.

Lenny admits he once felt ‘ashamed’ by the truth but has now decided to ‘own it’.

Speaking to The Guardian, Lenny said: ‘My story is an immigrant story. My story is of people moving from one country thousands of miles away to another and forming new links, new family and new relationships.

‘And that’s just what it is. It’s not illicit, it’s not salacious in any way. It’s a life thing.’

The comedian’s autobiography is out now (Picture: Rex Features)

Lenny’s relationship with his mother was a tumultuous one as he reveals how he was beaten throughout his childhood.

Before Winifred’s death in 1998, Lenny recalls how she changed once he became famous.

‘I felt that she was buying into the showbiz story and she was changing. Why was she changing? This is the woman who, up to five minutes ago, would backhand me or beat me or whatever, and now she’s calling me Lenny instead of Len,’ he said.

Lenny details his childhood and rise to fame in his new autobiography, Who Am I, Again? and reveals how he used to make bullies laugh even after being called the n-word.

The TV star writes: ‘For a brief period, I’d have a fight every single day with this kid.’

He’d say hateful things like, “Hey d**, hey n*****.” Every day, the same greeting as usual.

Lenny’s new autobiography, Who Am I Again? is out now.
